verses.verse: (vv 15, 31|JOL 2:1531; Num 10.9; Jer 4.5; Joel 1.15; Zeph 1.14-16) Blow the trumpet in Zion; sound the alarm on my holy mountain! Let all the inhabitants of the land tremble, for the day of the LORD is coming, it is near—

(Lam 1.12; Joel 1.2, 6; Am 5.18) a day of darkness and gloom, a day of clouds and thick darkness! Like blackness spread upon the mountains, a great and powerful army comes; their like has never been from of old, nor will be again after them in ages to come.

(Gen 2.8; Ps 105.34, 35; Isa 51.3; Joel 1.19, 20) Fire devours in front of them, and behind them a flame burns. Before them the land is like the garden of Eden, but after them a desolate wilderness, and nothing escapes them.
(Rev 9.7) They have the appearance of horses, and like war horses they charge.

(Isa 5.24; 30.30; Rev 9.9) As with the rumbling of chariots, they leap on the tops of the mountains, like the crackling of a flame of fire devouring the stubble, like a powerful army drawn up for battle.
(Isa 13.8; Jer 30.6; Nah 2.10) Before them peoples are in anguish; all faces grow pale. (Meaning of Heb uncertain)
Like warriors they charge; like soldiers they scale the wall. Each keeps to its own course; they do not swerve from their paths.
They do not jostle one another; each keeps to its own track; they burst through the weapons and are not halted.
(v 7|JOL 2:7; Jer 9.21; Jn 10.1) They leap upon the city; they run upon the walls; they climb up into the houses; they enter through the windows like a thief.
(v 15|JOL 2:15; Ps 18.7; Isa 13.10; Mt 24.29) The earth quakes before them; the heavens tremble. The sun and the moon are darkened, and the stars withdraw their shining.

(vv 2, 25|JOL 2:225; Jer 50.34; Joel 3.16; Am 1.2; Rev 18.8) The LORD utters his voice at the head of his army; how vast is his host! Numberless are those who obey his command. Truly the day of the LORD is great, terrible indeed—who can endure it?
(Jer 4.1; Hos 12.6) Yet even now, says the LORD, return to me with all your heart, with fasting, with weeping, and with mourning;

(2 Sam 1.11; Ps 34.18; Isa 57.15; Jer 18.8; 42.10; Jon 4.2) rend your hearts and not your clothing. Return to the LORD your God, for he is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, abounding in steadfast love, and relenting from punishment.
(Jer 26.3; Joel 1.9, 13; Hag 2.19) Who knows whether he will not turn and relent and leave a blessing behind him, a grain offering and a drink offering for the LORD your God?
(v 1|JOL 2:1; Num 10.3; Jer 36.9; Joel 1.14) Blow the trumpet in Zion; consecrate a fast; call a solemn assembly;
(Ex 19.10, 22; Ps 19.5) gather the people. Consecrate the congregation; assemble the aged; gather the children, even infants at the breast. Let the bridegroom leave his room and the bride her canopy.

(Deut 9.26-29; Isa 37.20; Ezek 8.16; Joel 1.9; Mt 23.35) Between the vestibule and the altar, let the priests, the ministers of the LORD, weep. Let them say, “Spare your people, O LORD, and do not make your heritage a mockery, a byword among the nations. Why should it be said among the peoples, ‘Where is their God?’ ”
God’s Response and Promise (Isa 60.10; Zech 1.14) Then the LORD became jealous for his land and had pity on his people.
(Ezek 34.29; 36.15; Hos 2.21, 22) In response to his people the LORD said: “I am sending you grain, wine, and oil, and you will be satisfied; and I will no more make you a mockery among the nations.

(Deut 11.24; Isa 34.3; Jer 1.14, 15; Am 4.10; Zech 14.8) I will remove the northern army far from you and drive it into a parched and desolate land, its front into the eastern sea and its rear into the western sea; its stench and foul smell will rise up.” Surely he has done great things!
Do not fear, O soil; be glad and rejoice, for the LORD has done great things!
(Ps 65.12, 13) Do not fear, you animals of the field, for the pastures of the wilderness are green; the tree bears its fruit; the fig tree and vine give their full yield.

(Deut 11.14; Ps 149.2; Isa 41.16; Jer 5.24; Hos 6.3) O children of Zion, be glad, and rejoice in the LORD your God, for he has given the early rain (Meaning of Heb uncertain) for your vindication; he has poured down for you abundant rain, the early and the later rain, as before.
The threshing floors shall be full of grain; the vats shall overflow with wine and oil.
(Joel 1.4) I will repay you for the years that the swarming locust has eaten, the hopper, the destroyer, and the cutter, my great army that I sent against you.

(Ps 67.5-7; Isa 25.1; 45.17; 62.9) You shall eat in plenty and be satisfied and praise the name of the LORD your God, who has dealt wondrously with you. And my people shall never again be put to shame.
(Isa 45.5, 21; 49.23; Joel 3.17, 21) You shall know that I am in the midst of Israel and that I, the LORD, am your God and there is no other. And my people shall never again be put to shame.

God’s Spirit Poured Out (Isa 40.5; Acts 2.17-21) (3.1 in Heb) Then afterward I will pour out my spirit on all flesh; your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, and your young men shall see visions.
(1 Cor 12.13; Gal 3.28) Even on the male and female slaves, in those days I will pour out my spirit.
(Mt 24.29; Lk 21.11, 25; Acts 2.19) I will show portents in the heavens and on the earth, blood and fire and columns of smoke.
(Isa 13.9, 10; Mal 4.1, 5; Mt 24.29; Rev 6.12) The sun shall be turned to darkness and the moon to blood, before the great and terrible day of the LORD comes.

(Isa 46.13; Mic 4.7; Rom 9.27) Then everyone who calls on the name of the LORD shall be saved, for in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem there shall be those who escape, as the LORD has said, and among the survivors shall be those whom the LORD calls.
